bibl.title: Letter from C[harles] R. G[reenleaf] to Walter Reed, July 1[-], 1887

div1.p: The original draft of Greenleaf's letter informs Reed that the treating of several pension cases each month does not warrant his being excused from performing that duty.

div1.head: Letter from C[harles] R. G[reenleaf] to Walter Reed, July 1[-], 1887
div1.p:
In reply to yr letter of the [unclear]ulto the
S. G. instructs me to say that an average of not
quite 2two pension cases per month have been sent
to you for examn, during the eighteen months ending
June 30/87. and is of the opinion that this slight
[unclear]additional service shld neither be a burden nor
interfere with the proper performance of yr duties
as Med Offr of the Post, which are represented
by your reports for the nine mnths ending April
1st 87 as follows:
Daily average number of offr & enlisted men treated [unclear]
aggregate number of civilians (including convicts) treated [unclear]
aggregate number of recruits examine
As the examn of pensioners and their
claims is an important part of the duty required
of officers of the Medical Departm he does not consider that
the facts rend in the case will justify, render it necessary to
excuse you from its performance
